Survey.title: Hereditary Cancer Risk
Survey.Splash:
This application will help you determine if a person is appropriate for cancer genetics risk evaluation for hereditary breast and ovarian cancer.
The 2005 U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommendations on genetic risk assessment and BRCA mutation testing for breast and ovarian cancer susceptibility are used for unaffected women. This is a grade B USPSTF recommendation and according to the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act insurers are prohibited from charging co-payments or deductibles for Level B preventive care.
The 2011 Breast and Ovarian Cancer Genetic Assessment from the National Comprehensive Cancer Network are used for women affected with breast and/or ovarian cancer and for men.
Disclaimer: this application is not a substitute for medical evaluation, diagnosis, and treatment.

ResultList.Result:
This survey has determined there is an average risk for hereditary breast and/or ovarian cancer:
Based on the information provided, a breast/ovarian cancer genetics risk evaluation is not recommended.
This application does not assess risk for other cancers so if there are concerns about the potential for other hereditary cancer syndromes, cancer genetics risk evaluation may still be indicated.
To contact the Cancer Genetics Program at the James Cancer Hospital and Solove Research Institute call toll free 1-888-329-1654 or email genetics.clinic@osumc.edu
To find a genetic counselor in your area, click here: www.nsgc.org

This survey has determined there is an elevated risk for hereditary breast and ovarian cancer:
Cancer genetics risk evaluation with consideration of genetic testing for mutations in the BRCA1/2 genes is warranted.
To contact the Cancer Genetics Program at the James Cancer Hospital and Solove Research Institute call toll free 1-888-329-1654 or email genetics.clinic@osumc.edu
To find a genetic counselor in your area, click here: www.nsgc.org
